case_name: State of West Bengal v. the respondent

facts.text: Appeal by the State of West Bengal from a judgment of a Full Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta quashing the conviction of the respondent by the Special Court.

anchor.surface_text: Patanjali Sastri, C.J. This is an appeal by the State of West Bengal from a judgment of a Full Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta quashing the conviction of the respondent by the Special Court es

facts.text: Special Court established under section 3 of the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949 (Ordinance No. 3 of 1949).

anchor.surface_text: tablished under section 3 of the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, 1949,  Ordinance No. 3 of 1949  which was replaced in March, 1950, by the West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950,  West Bengal Act X of 1950

facts.text: Ordinance replaced in March 1950 by West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950 (West Bengal Act X of 1950).

anchor.surface_text: which was replaced in March, 1950, by the West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950,  West Bengal Act X of 1950   hereinafter referred to as the Act . The respondent and 49 other persons were charged with various offences alleged

facts.text: Respondent and 49 other persons charged with various offences committed during raid as armed gang on Jessop Factory at Dum Dum.

anchor.surface_text: as the Act . The respondent and 49 other persons were charged with various offences alleged to have been committed by them in the course of their raid as an armed gang on a certain factory known as the Jessop Factory at Dum Dum,

facts.text: Convicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by Special Court.

anchor.surface_text: and they were convicted and sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment by the Special Court to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a notification dated 26th January, 1950,

facts.text: Case sent to Special Court by Governor of West Bengal by notification dated 26th January 1950 under section 5(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: by the Special Court to which the case was sent for trial by the Governor of West Bengal by a notification dated 26th January, 1950, in exercise of the powers conferred by section 5 (1) of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent applied to High Court under article 226 for writ of certiorari quashing conviction on ground section 5(1) unconstitutional under article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondent applied to the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the conviction and sentence on the ground that the Special Court had no jurisdiction to try the case

facts.text: High Court Full Bench quashed conviction and directed trial according to law.

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as section 5 (1), under which it was sent to that Court for trial, was unconstitutional and void under article 13 (2) as it denied to the respondent the equal protection of the laws enjoined by article 14.

facts.text: Raid took place on February 26, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The raid took place on February 26, 1949. The accused or most of them were arrested some time after the Ordinance was promulgated.

facts.text: West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance promulgated on August 17, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1949, an Ordinance, known as the West Bengal Special Courts Ordinance, was promulgated by the Governor of West Bengal under section 88 of the Government of India Act, 1935.

facts.text: Notification directing case of Anwar Ali Sarkar and 49 co-accused to Special Judge dated 25th January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On 25th of January, 1950, the State Government by a notification directed that the case of Anwar Ali and his 49 co-accused should be tried by Mr. S. N. Guha Roy

facts.text: Special Judge S. N. Guha Roy convicted accused on 31st March 1951.

anchor.surface_text: by his judgment dated the 31st of March, 1951, the Special Judge convicted the accused under various sections of the Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: High Court Special Bench judgment dated 28th August 1951 quashing proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of a Special Bench of the Calcutta High Court dated the 28th of August, 1951,

facts.text: Notification covered five more cases besides Anwar Ali's, all related to armed raid on Jessop premises.

anchor.surface_text: The notification by which the case of Anwar Ali Sarkar (the respondent herein) was directed to be tried by the special court did not relate merely to that case but covered five more cases

facts.text: Crimes of utmost brutality committed on large scale during raid.

anchor.surface_text: in each of which the accused were several in number. In Anwar Alis case itself, there were 49 other accused. All these cases related to the armed raid on the premises of Jessop Co.

facts.text: Act came into effect on 15th March 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On 15th March, 1950, this Ordinance was superseded and replaced by the West Bengal Special Courts Act which contained provisions almost identical with those of the Ordinance.

facts.text: Special Judge Shri S. N. Guha Roy appointed on October 28, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On October 28, 1949, when the Ordinance was still in force, the West Bengal Government appointed Shri S. N. Guha Roy, who was then the Sessions Judge of Alipore, a Special Judge,

facts.text: Formal complaint lodged before Special Judge on April 2, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: A formal complaint was lodged before the Special Judge in respect of these 50 persons on April 2, 1950, that is to say, after the Special Courts Act was passed,

facts.text: Cases arisen out of serious disturbances partaking of organised revolt.

anchor.surface_text: All these cases again have arisen out of serious disturbances which, according to the prosecution, partook of the nature of an organised revolt.

facts.text: Constitution came into force on 26th January 1950.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of the Constitution of India, which came into force on the 26th of January, 1950, applied to his case also.

holdings.text: Section 5(1) of the West Bengal Special Courts Act, read as empowering the State Government to direct a Special Court to try cases requiring speedier trial, does not violate Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: The principle of construction applicable here is perhaps nowhere better stated than by Lord Tenterden C.J. in Halton v. Cove (1830) 1 B & Ad. 538, 558 It is very true, as was argued for the plaintiff, that the enacting words of an Act of Parliament are not always to be limited by the words of the preamble, but must in many cases go beyond it. Yet, on a sound construction of every Act of Parliament, I take it the words of the enacting part must be confined to that which is the plain object and general intention of the legislature in passing the Act, and that the preamble affords a good clue to discover what that object was.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction limits general words in s5(1) to preamble object of speedier trials; discretion not arbitrary if exercised bona fide; wide legislative latitude in classification; presumption of good faith.

holdings.text: Section 5(1) is not discriminatory on its face and vests no arbitrary power when understood as confined to cases needing speedier trial.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the foregoing discussion it seems to me difficult to hold that section 5 (1) in whole or in part is discriminatory. It does not, either in terms or by necessary implication, discriminate as between persons or classes of persons nor does it purport to deny to any one equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No facial discrimination; notifications apply procedure; US precedents allow administrative discretion if not arbitrary.

holdings.text: The notification referring the case to Special Court is valid and not discriminatory given exceptional facts of armed raid and brutality.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these facts it seems to me impossible to say the State Government has acted arbitrarily or with a discriminatory intention in referring these cases to the Special Court, for there are obviously special features which mark off this group of cases as requiring speedier disposal than would be possible under the ordinary procedure, and the charge of discriminatory treatment must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show organized revolt, brutality; no purposeful discrimination proven; Snowden v. Hughes requires clear intent.

holdings.text: Section 5 of the Act offends Article 14 and is unconstitutional and void.

anchor.surface_text: it seems to me that section 5 of the Act, or at least that part of it with which alone we are concerned in this appeal, does offend against article 14 of the Constitution and is therefore unconstitutional and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Verbatim pre-Constitution copy ignores CrPC classification by gravity; two procedures side-by-side lead to anomalies; no reasonable classification; speedier trial too vague.

holdings.text: Section 5 of the West Bengal Special Courts Act is hit by Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 of the West Bengal Special Courts Act is hit by article 14 of the Constitution inasmuch as it mentions no basis for the differential treatment prescribed in the Act for trial of criminals in certain cases and for certain offences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reasonable classification; speedier trial vague, no objective test; special procedure prejudicial (no committal, jury, etc.); arbitrary executive discretion.

holdings.text: The Act is invalid because it offends Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: what we have to decide is whether it is invalid because it offends against article 14 of the Constitution. In dealing with this question, the following facts have to be borne in mind - The framers of the Act have merely copied the provisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ignores CrPC gravity classification; allows arbitrary selection; dual procedures discriminatory.

holdings.text: Provision of section 5(1) and notifications ultra vires as conflicting with Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: the whole controversy centers round the point as to whether the provision of section 5 (1) of the West Bengal Special Courts Act, 1950, as well as certain notifications issued under it are ultra vires the Constitution by reason of their being in conflict with article 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No classification basis; executive picks cases arbitrarily; prejudicial procedure without rational nexus.

holdings.text: Special procedure under the Act not per se prejudicial to fair trial.

anchor.surface_text: While some of these departures from the normal procedure might, in practice, operate in some respects to the disadvantage of persons tried before the Special Court, it cannot be said that they derogate from the essential requirements of a fair and impartial trial, so as to give rise, from their very nature, to an inference of a discriminatory design.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deviations aimed at expedition, not inherently unfair.

anchor.surface_text: The principle of construction applicable here is perhaps nowhere better stated than by Lord Tenterden C.J. in Halton v. Cove (1830) 1 B & Ad. 538, 558 It is very true, as was argued for the plaintiff, that the enacting words of an Act of Parliament are not always to be limited by the words of the preamble, but must in many cases go beyond it. Yet, on a sound construction of every Act of Parliament, I take it the words of the enacting part must be confined to that which is the plain object and general intention of the legislature in passing the Act, and that the preamble affords a good clue to discover what that object was.
